How cute are these plants??!! The local Beta Iota Chapter sent them for our 13 Mexico 59 teachers who are brand new to Mexico and brand new teachers!

This is definitely the year for some encouragement for educators, and we appreciate that the Beta Iota ladies support of teaching, learning, and caring at Mexico 59! #MEX59TLC

According to one study, "the rate in the U.S. of beginning teachers leaving the profession in the first year is a little more than 10%; with 33% leaving by Year 3 and 46% by Year 5."

The Beta Iota Chapter is part of the Delta Kappa Gamma International Society for key women educators. These ladies usually visit us during New Teacher Institute, but, due to COVID-19, they are offering occasional gifts of support for our new staff.

Our Bright Futures Advisory Board was so happy to finally meet face-to-face again this week! We discussed many ideas on how to support local children during COVID-19, especially through the Lunch Buddy program.

Bright Futures Mexico strives to help students achieve success by matching student needs with resources through partnerships between the schools and the community.

Those partnership areas include faith-based, social/human services, businesses, and parents and volunteers will be asked to give of their "time, talent, and treasure" to help children.

Nicole Mann, Valedictorian

The Salutatorian award is the second-highest MHS academic award. According to board policy, the student must undertake a challenging course of studies and have the second-highest class GPA with at least a score of 26 on the ACT.

Results of the Audrain County Municipal Election show Dustin Pascoe, Kelli Teel, and Todd Yager have won seats on the Board of Education. We welcome Mr. Pascoe and Ms. Teel back to the Board and are excited to welcome Mr. Yager for his first term. Even more important than tracking or blocking online content is having conversations with your kids about responsible and safe online behavior. Monitoring usage and having family rules like no phones after bedtime, no game systems in the bedrooms, will help but here are some other basic safety rules to follow:

Never share personal information online.
Never send pictures or ask for pictures.
Do not share passwords online.
If you receive information that you did not ask for alert an adult (pictures, wanting to meet up).
If you feel like you are or have been threatened by email, text, or message, alert an adult.
Always tell a parent if you are feeling uncomfortable with interactions online.

Talk to your children! Keeping open lines of communication and make sure they come to you or a trusted adult when they have problems online.

Read more on "Keeping your kids safe online" in this week's article from Christina McCaw, Director of Social Emotional Learning & Behavior at https://www.mexicoschools.net/news/what_s_new/keeping_kids_safe_online
